Class pj2

  • java.lang.Object
    • pj2

  • public class pj2
extends Object
    Class pj2 is the PJ2 job and task launcher main program.

    Usage: java pj2 [threads=threads] [schedule=schedule] [chunk=chunk] [nodeName=nodeName] [cores=cores] [gpus=gpus] [workers=workers] [masterSchedule=masterSchedule] [masterChunk=masterChunk] [tracker=host[:port]] [listen=host[:port]] [debug=message[,message...]] [jvmFlags=flag[,flag]] [jar=file] [timelimit=timelimit] jobOrTaskClass [arg ...]

    PJ2 is designed for writing two kinds of parallel programs: tightly coupled single-node and loosely coupled multi-node.

    Tightly coupled single-node parallel programs. A tightly coupled single-node parallel program is intended to run on one multicore node. The program consists of multiple threads that run in parallel on separate cores. The threads communicate and coordinate by reading and writing variables in shared memory.

    This kind of PJ2 program is expressed as a subclass of class Task. The program is executed by running the pj2 program as follows:

    $ java pj2 MainTask arg ...

    The above command runs class MainTask, a subclass of class Task. Replace MainTask with the fully-qualified class name of the desired task subclass. The pj2 program creates an instance of the task subclass, then calls that task's main() method, passing in an array of the command line argument strings (zero or more). The main() method carries out the computation. When the main() method returns, the pj2 program terminates.

    The computation can contain sequential statements executed by a single thread, interspersed with parallel statements executed by multiple threads. Running on a multicore computer, the Java Virtual Machine (JVM) schedules each thread on a separate core, thus executing the program in parallel.

    Loosely coupled multi-node parallel programs. A loosely coupled multi-node parallel program is intended to run on multiple nodes. The nodes may be located in a cluster parallel computer, in a grid, or in a cloud. The program consists of multiple Tasks that run in parallel on separate nodes. The tasks coordinate and communicate with each other by reading and writing Tuples in tuple space. The tasks are intended to be coarse-grained, meaning each task runs for minutes or hours, not milliseconds. The tasks are intended to communicate small to medium amounts of data via tuple space, not enormous quantities of data.

    This kind of PJ2 program is expressed as a subclass of class Job. The program is executed by running the pj2 program as follows:

    $ java pj2 jar=file MainJob arg ...

    The above command runs class MainJob, a subclass of class Job. Replace MainJob with the fully-qualified class name of the desired job subclass. The pj2 program creates an instance of the job subclass, then calls that job's main() method, passing in an array of the command line argument strings (zero or more). The main() method defines Rules that specify which Tasks are to be executed as part of the job. The pj2 program creates and executes those tasks, which carry out the job's computation. The tasks may execute in the pj2 program's process or on computational nodes that are part of a cluster, grid, or cloud. When all the tasks have finished executing, the pj2 program terminates.

    Running on a cluster, grid, or cloud, the program executes each task on a separate node, thus executing the program in parallel. Each task receives input tuples that are taken out of tuple space, performs computations, and generates output tuples that are written into tuple space. Each task executes independently of other tasks. All inter-task coordination and communication goes through tuple space.

    Properties. Certain properties of the job or task can be specified on the pj2 command line by including the appropriate option before the job or task class name. These override the default property values. The properties are:

    • threads specifies the number of threads that will execute a parallel for loop. Specify threads=all to indicate that a parallel for loop will be executed by as many threads as there are cores on the machine on which the task is running. The default is threads=all. See the Job.threads() or Task.threads() method for further information.

    • schedule specifies how the iterations of a parallel for loop are partitioned among the threads executing the parallel for loop. The default is a fixed schedule. See the Job.schedule() or Task.schedule() method for further information.

    • chunk specifies how the iterations of a parallel for loop are partitioned among the threads executing the parallel for loop. The interpretation of the default chunk property depends on the schedule property. See the Job.chunk() or Task.chunk() method for further information.

    • nodeName specifies the name of the node on which a task must run. Specify nodeName=any to indicate that a task can run on any node. The default is nodeName=any. See the Job.nodeName() or Task.nodeName() method for further information.

    • cores specifies the number of CPU cores a task requires. Specify cores=all to indicate that a task requires all the CPU cores on the node. The default is cores=all. See the Job.cores() or Task.cores() method for further information.

    • gpus specifies the number of GPU accelerators a task requires. The default is none (0). See the Job.gpus() or Task.gpus() method for further information.

    • workers specifies the number of worker tasks that will execute a master-worker cluster parallel for loop. The default is one worker task. See the Job.workers() method for further information.

    • masterSchedule specifies how the iterations of a master-worker cluster parallel for loop are partitioned among the worker tasks executing the parallel for loop. The default is a fixed schedule. See the Job.masterSchedule() method for further information.

    • masterChunk specifies how the iterations of a master-worker cluster parallel for loop are partitioned among the worker tasks executing the parallel for loop. The interpretation of the default masterChunk property depends on the masterSchedule property. See the Job.masterChunk() method for further information.

    • tracker specifies the host and port at which the Tracker Daemon is listening for connections from jobs. See the Job.trackerHost() and Job.trackerPort() methods for further information.

    • listen specifies the host and port at which the job itself will listen for connections from the nodes that will run the job's tasks. See the Job.listenHost() and Job.listenPort() methods for further information.

    • debug tells a job to print a certain debugging message or messages. Multiple messages may be specified, separated by commas (no spaces). Specify debug=all to turn on all debugging messages. Specify debug=none to turn off all debugging messages. See the Job.debug() method for further information.

    • jvmFlags specifies one or more flags that are included on the command lines of the JVMs that run each of the tasks in the job. Multiple flags may be specified, separated by commas (no spaces). See the Job.jvmFlags() method for further information.

    • jar specifies the Java archive (JAR) file that contains the class files needed by a job and its tasks. For further information, see class Job.

    • timelimit specifies a time limit in seconds for the job. The default is no time limit. See the Job.timeLimit() method for further information.

    Abnormal termination. If code in a job or task throws an exception that propagates out of the main() method, the pj2 program prints an exception stack trace and terminates.

    Code in a job or task must not call the System.exit() method. If a job or task needs to terminate itself, the job or task should throw an exception that propagates out of every method without being caught, such as a TerminateException or any other runtime exception. The exception's detail message can explain why the job or task terminated. This exception propagates out of the main() method and causes the pj2 program to terminate.

    See Also:
    edu.rit.pj2, Job, Task
